comment._content: I don't know why a line from point C to point D would not have sufficed.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
To answer your question,   they already know where C and D are but they don't know the distance between them.  They don't have a steel tape measure 2000 metres long,  and even if they did,  they can't measure it across the harbour.
But they do have a steel tape measure 500 metres long,   and a big lawn at Government house.  So they mark out 2 points in the garden at Government house,   and they know exactly the distance between them with their steel tape measure.   They they measure the angles to C and D.  After they do this,  they can use trigonometry to measure the exact distance between C and D  so they know how long to make the bridge.
The description that they needed to do this to lay out the centreline from C to D is not an accurate description in my opinion.   They had C and D laid out.  The purpose of this rigmarole was to determine the exact distance from C to D.
